title: Singular Value Decomposition (SVD)
contentHtml: Solve a matrix decomposition problem step-by-step using SVD.

problem.statementHtml: Given a matrix A, find its singular value decomposition (SVD) A = UΣVᵀ.
hints: Hint: SVD is a factorization of A into three matrices.
problem.solutionHtml:
Solution steps:

  • Step 1: Compute the covariance matrix Σ.
  • Step 2: Find the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of Σ.
  • Step 3: Construct the orthogonal matrices U and Vᵀ from the eigenvectors.

workedExample.problemHtml: Consider a matrix A with singular value decomposition A = UΣVᵀ. Compute Σ and Vᵀ given U.

steps.explanation: We compute Σ as the average of the outer product of U and A.

steps.description: Find the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of Σ.
steps.explanation: We diagonalize Σ to obtain its eigenvectors and eigenvalues.

steps.description: Construct the orthogonal matrices U and Vᵀ from the eigenvectors.
steps.explanation: We construct Vᵀ as the matrix of eigenvectors scaled by their eigenvalues.

intuition: SVD is a powerful tool for dimensionality reduction and feature extraction in machine learning.

contentHtml: Solve a matrix decomposition problem step-by-step using SVD.

problem.statementHtml:
Decompose the following matrix into its singular values, left and right singular vectors:

\[A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 4 \end{bmatrix}\]
hints: Hint: Use SVD to diagonalize A
problem.solutionHtml:
To solve this problem, we'll follow these steps:

  • Step 1: Compute the covariance matrix Σ.
  • Step 2: Find the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of Σ.
  • Step 3: Use the eigenvectors to form U and V.

steps.description: Find the eigenvectors and eigenvalues of Σ.
steps.explanation: Eigenvectors help us find the directions of maximum variance.

steps.description: Use the eigenvectors to form U and V.
steps.explanation: Now we have our SVD decomposition!

intuition: SVD helps us understand the underlying structure of a matrix by decomposing it into its most important features.
